title: Defensiveness & Openness
description: Explore how open or defensive you are during disagreements

questions.text: I can hear my partner's concerns without immediately defending myself.

therapeutic.rationale: Defensiveness blocks connection. When you can hear a concern before defending, you show your partner their feelings matter—even if you see things differently.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner immediately defends, explore what triggers the defense. Feeling attacked? Shame? Understanding the trigger helps pause the automatic response.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to listen before defending creates receptive dialogue.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What happens inside you when your partner raises a concern? What makes you defensive?

questions.text: I sense openness in my partner when I share concerns with them.

therapeutic.rationale: Shutting down or counter-attacking are defensive moves that prevent real dialogue. Partners who can receive feedback openly create space for growth.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner experiences defensiveness, explore how feedback is given and received. Sometimes delivery triggers defense; sometimes it's the receiver's pattern.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual openness to feedback creates a growth-oriented relationship.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner typically respond to feedback? How do you?

questions.text: I can admit when I've contributed to a problem.

therapeutic.rationale: Taking responsibility for your part—without taking all the blame—shows maturity and moves conflicts toward resolution. Refusing to own any contribution keeps you stuck.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner struggles to admit contribution, explore what makes it hard. Fear of being blamed for everything? Shame? Creating safety for admission helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual willingness to admit contribution accelerates conflict resolution.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How easy or hard is it for you to admit your part in problems?

questions.text: We can talk about what went wrong without it becoming about who's at fault.

therapeutic.rationale: Focusing on fault creates winners and losers. Focusing on what went wrong—the pattern, the misunderstanding—creates partners solving a problem together.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If conversations become about fault, notice who shifts to blame and when. Breaking the pattern requires catching it in the moment.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared focus on understanding rather than blaming creates collaborative problem-solving.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do your discussions about problems focus on fault or understanding?

questions.text: There's room for both of us to be right about different parts of a conflict.

therapeutic.rationale: Most conflicts contain valid points on both sides. When there's room for both perspectives to have merit, partners don't have to defeat each other to be heard.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel room for both to be right, explore what creates the either/or dynamic. Zero-sum thinking makes every conflict a battle.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared acceptance that both can be right creates generous conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Can you both be right about different aspects of a disagreement? What helps that?
